definition: Zhao Erxun (1844-1927), modern historian, compiled the Draft History of the Qing dynasty 清史稿
to surpass (old)
surname Zhao/one of the seven states during the Warring States Period (476-220 BC)/the Former Zhao 前趙 (304-329) and Later Zhao 後趙 (319-350), states of the Sixteen Kingdoms
variant of 爾|尔[er3]
thus/so/like that/you/thou
to obey/one of the Eight Trigrams 八卦[ba1 gua4], symbolizing wood and wind/☴/ancient Chinese compass point: 135° (southeast)
Zhang Zhidong (1837-1909), prominent politician in late Qing
Xu Shichang (1855-1939), politician associated with the Northern Warlords, president of China in 1921
Li Hung-chang or Li Hongzhang (1823-1901), Qing dynasty general, politician and diplomat
Duan Qirui (1864-1936), commander of Beiyang Army under Yuan Shikai, then politician and powerful warlord
the Qing court (as government of China)
Zuo Zongtang (1812-1885), Chinese administrator and military leader
Tang Yulin (1871-1937), minor warlord in northeast China, sometime governor of Chengde 承德, mostly poor in battle but very successful at accumulating personal wealth
Zhang Zuolin (c. 1873-1928), warlord of Manchuria 1916-1928
Feng Yuxiang (1882-1948), warlord during Republic of China, strongly critical of Chiang Kai-shek
Cao Kun (1862-1938), one of the Northern Warlords
the Warlord government of Northern China that developed from the Qing Beiyang army 北洋軍閥|北洋军阀 after the Xinhai revolution of 1911
Ni Sichong (1868-1924), general closely linked to Yuan Shikai 袁世凱|袁世凯 during his unsuccessful 1915 bid for Empire
Yuan Shikai (1859-1916), senior general of late Qing, subsequently warlord and self-proclaimed emperor of China
Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat
Zhang Xun (1854-1923), Qing loyalist general who attempted to restore the abdicated emperor Puyi 溥儀|溥仪[Pu3 yi2] to the throne in the Manchu Restoration of 1917 張勳復辟|张勋复辟[Zhanɡ1 Xun1 Fu4 bi4]
Zhang Yinhuan (1837-1900), late Qing politician and senior Chinese diplomat
